What did early Canadian farmers eat?

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Sask.

Name: Robert Lindlaw
Address: [illegible]
Birthplace: Rosslyn, Scotland

1. HOUSEHOLD HISTORY
   What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1892
   Where did you set up housekeeping? 6 mi. S.W. of Estevan
   Where had you been living before that? Heathland
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 5
   How far was it to your nearest store? 6 mi.
   How often could a visit be made to the store? once a week
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? flour, homestead corn meal, sugar, tea, dried apples, pine nuts, condensed milk, salt

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Local Mill flour
   In what quantities did you buy it? 4 lb. 10 lb.
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 150 cents
   How much did you use graham flour? 20
   Whole wheat flour? 20
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   How far away? 40 mi. that year?
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 75 cents
   What other grain products did you use? [illegible]
   Cornmeal? [illegible]
   Whole wheat? [illegible]
   Other? [illegible]
   Did you grind your own oatmeal for porridge? Yes

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates here please).

Nearly all food came in the same style in bulk and was sealed in paper bags. The first package I ever saw was "Saladini" sugar dried apples. Soda would come in boxes. Raisins came in soft boxes.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Father, Mother & children 2yo, 8yo
Breakfast would be mostly porridge, ground wheat or granulated oatmeal & eggs.
Dinner Salt pork potatoes onion apple pie.
Supper eggs potatoes meat & butter.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? _________________. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. If you are not sure about the date, give the approximate month, season or year.

Father, Mother & children 27 & 28

Breakfast: toast & scrambled eggs

Dinner: roast pork, potatoes, mixed vegetables

Supper: eggs, apples & butter

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Kansas? Approximately how many people attended?

19. Have you ever refused to allow starvation levels to exist due to poverty? If so, how did you do it?
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Most people had up a supply of meat flour outstanding in the fall to do their best with that was the main articles of their food with the addition of prunes evaporated apples & molasses.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Nearly all groceries were sold in bulk there was very little packaged food. Batada tea was the first package tea about 1895. Pickles were sold in wooden jars about 3 pints. In the early days there was quite a lot of British food in the stores in Crosse & Blackwell's fruit & pickles, Dundee marmalade, Huntley & Palmers biscuits, Epsom cocoa.
